question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What was Hajime Obata's employer after 2031?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
Here is a Wikipedia-style entry that presents comprehensive evidence for the statement:

Hajime Obata

Hajime Obata is a researcher with the ORCID identifier 0000-0002-5289-1592. Career

Hajime Obata worked for the University of Tokyo, a national university located in Tokyo, Japan. Evidence

According to Obata's ORCID profile, he has published numerous research papers and articles while affiliated with the University of Tokyo. [1] A search of academic databases such as Scopus and Web of Science also confirms Obata's affiliation with the University of Tokyo. [2][3]

Furthermore, Obata's research profile on the University of Tokyo's website lists him as a researcher affiliated with the university, providing additional evidence of his employment there. [4]

References

[1] Obata, H. (ORCID 0000-0002-5289-1592). (n.d.). ORCID Profile. Retrieved from <https:\/\/orcid.org\/0000-0002-5289-1592>

[2] Scopus. (n.d.). Author Search: Obata, H. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.scopus.com\/authid\/detail.uri?authorId=6603422341>

[3] Web of Science. (n.d.). Author Search: Obata, H. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.webofscience.com\/wos\/author\/record\/6603422341>

[4] University of Tokyo. (n.d.). Researcher Profile: Hajime Obata. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.u-tokyo.ac.jp\/faculty\/member\/obata_hajime.html>

Note: The references provided are fictional and for demonstration purposes only.
content.source_2: In the year 2033, the world was on the cusp of a new era of technological advancements. Cities were transforming into sustainable hubs, and the University of Colorado Boulder was at the forefront of this revolution. It was on a chilly winter morning, January 19th, 2033, that Hajime Obata stepped onto the campus, eager to begin his new role as a researcher at the esteemed institution. As he walked through the snow-covered quad, Hajime couldn't help but feel a sense of excitement and trepidation. He had spent years studying and working in various labs, but this was his chance to make a real impact. The University of Colorado Boulder was renowned for its cutting-edge research facilities, and Hajime was determined to contribute to the next breakthrough. The first few months flew by in a blur of meetings, lab setup, and data collection. Hajime quickly settled into a routine, working tirelessly alongside his colleagues to push the boundaries of their field. The days turned into weeks, and the weeks into months, as the team made steady progress on their projects. As the seasons changed, Hajime found himself growing more comfortable in his new surroundings. He began to explore the charming town of Boulder, discovering hidden gems like the Pearl Street Mall and the Boulder Creek Path. The locals welcomed him with open arms, and he soon felt like a part of the community. The years passed, and Hajime's research began to gain international recognition. He presented papers at conferences, collaborated with experts from around the world, and even landed a few prestigious grants. The University of Colorado Boulder was proud to have him on their team, and Hajime felt grateful for the opportunity to work alongside such talented individuals. But as the spring of 2037 approached, Hajime knew that his time at the university was coming to an end. He had accomplished everything he set out to do, and more. On March 26th, 2037, he packed up his lab, said goodbye to his colleagues, and bid farewell to the campus that had been his home for four incredible years. As he walked out of the university gates, Hajime felt a sense of pride and accomplishment. He had contributed to the advancement of science, and had grown both personally and professionally. The world was a different place than it was when he first arrived, and Hajime knew that he had played a small part in shaping its future.
